ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about child development, developing curriculum for young children, and the role of the teacher in the classroom. The role of the teacher is much more complex and nuanced than I had originally thought, especially when it comes to encouraging the children to become inquisitive learners, instead of just drilling information into their minds. We learned a little about racism and talking to children about differences, which I found to be very illuminating. I learned about the role of blocks in the preschool, and how mathematics skills (sorting, classifying, ranking) can be taught in a fun manner. One of the biggest takeaways I got from this class is that early childhood educators are essential for creating young, inquisitive members of our society, and they should definitely be paid and valued by our community more!

I learned SO much from this course. Not only do you get a glimpse into the history of education, you also learn to develop a really strong understanding of children, how they learn, and what is important for child development. I got to observe a child once a week which also helped me develop a relationship with him. Overall, I feel that I gained a tremendous amount of knowledge and insights from this course.

I learned a lot about observing children and what one can gain from this. The class also makes you reflect a lot about your own childhood and your own life which was one of the best parts of the class.
Developmental psychology, scaffolding play for children, developmental stages and education
new way of writing, new way of understanding childhood education

I came in with very little understanding of the world of early childhood education. I now feel like I have a good foundational understanding of curriculum, child development for ages less than six, the role of teachers and parents, and current issues in the field.
I developed observation and writing skills

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: the weekly in-person observation of my child was so much fun and honestly the highlight of my week. I got to observe the development of my young child (she was 11 months when I first saw her, and is now about 15 months old!) which was pretty awesome. 

Weaknesses: not all of my peers were able to secure in-person shadowing opportunities, which was kinda disappointing. I hope next year the shadowing component can be in person for everyone!

There were assigned readings each week which helped with comprehension. It was also largely discussion-based which was also great. Guest lectures, videos, and other materials were also used to supplement learning.

Strengths: Professor Horwitz is such an incredible and kind professor. I think the observation of the children really allowed me to learn so much more than I could have by just reading about early childhood education and development.  Weakness: None.
This course is one of the most well taught at Yale. I have no suggestions for improvement.
Very involved, firsthand experience with young children. Class discussions were great, though guest lectures were a bit too frequent.
amazing to observe a child and all the lectures

This course is wonderfully taught and relies on observations of children to supplement the material discussed in class. The only limitation to this year's class was the inability to observe children in a daycare setting at Calvin Hill, but this most likely (hopefully) will not apply to future semesters.

it was nice to have so many speakers, but i would have liked to have a class hearing from Professor Horwitz about her experience and career (this was interspersed throughout the course, but it would have been nice to hear more!!)

I like the structure of the journals. I think the materials exploration was a bit rushed in that we found out about it close to when it was due, but it ended up working out and I think the timeline will work out better next year after we were the guinea pig year.

strengths: even virtually loved observing!

weaknesses: more of a leminar or lecture than a true seminar

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The seminar format of this course worked fine online. We were able to discuss the material productively. I am not sure how much more utility this class might have had if it was delivered in person. It might have been easier for Prof Horwitz to show us different materials, probably.
I think everything succeeded. I feel as if I did not miss out on much except maybe the unperson observations, but the zoom ones I still had were enjoyable.
The virtual format was great! Obviously an in person observation would have been more fun and involved, but we did our best

Our class discussions and conversations were still able to happen over zoom, but discourse did not flow as naturally as it might have otherwise in person. There was a portion of the class dedicated to student-led presentations of curriculum plans, which translated pretty well through zoom.
it was very discussion based which was good for engagement!
Overall I think our virtual seminar format was successful. I do wish there had been more chances for small group discussions in breakout rooms.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I would take this course again, for sure. It was my favorite class this term, and ranks pretty highly amongst my other Yale courses. It provides an experience like no other, and honestly, is probably a good idea for anyone who is interested in having children in the future.
PLEASE take this course if you're interested in education and children. It truly was an incredible class.

I would 100% recommend this course. Professor Horwitz cares a lot about the subject and her students. The class may have a lot of writing, but the style of writing makes it much easier to write and much more enjoyable. Grading was extremely fair and there was always great feedback. If you are at all interested, you should take it.
I would highly recommend this course to others! Professor Horwitz is an amazing instructor!

Yes, I would recommend this course to any psychology major, anyone interested in education, or anyone that enjoys working with children. It was more than a class. It was truly a fulfilling experience. This course allows its students to take the driver seat and get everything they want out of it.
Yes! Great course on learning how children work, and how to facilitate a successful early childhood education experience.
YES

Absolutely! This course gave me a new perspective on early child care and education and Professor Horwitz is a wonderful teacher. I would absolutely recommend this to any student, especially those who are thinking of going into education.
yes! Professor Horwitz is amazing and you really learn a new way of writing and get great feedback on essays
If they genuinely have an interest in the subject, even if they just think they want to learn more about children, I would recommend it.
yes

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class consisted of an online seminar (Tuesday afternoons) and an additional observation component. Each student had to find their own observation opportunity. Some of my peers observed their child over Zoom, or Facetime with relatives. I saw my child in-person, at their home each week.
Weekly zoom with child
N/A
video observation of children
